blocks.title: Free Hosting Platforms Comparison
rows: GitHub Pages
Completely free, best for static sites; seamless with GitHub Repos/Actions; supports custom domains and auto SSL; beginner-friendly with rich tutorials
Static content only; no built-in backend/Serverless; storage ~1GB, ~10 deploys/hour; slower access in some regions
Netlify
CI/CD linked to Git with Deploy Preview; built-in Functions, forms, and auth; global CDN with custom domains and SSL; highly automated
Free plan uses credits (~300/month); limited function runtime and memory; high traffic and advanced features require paid plan
Vercel
Zero-config deploy, optimized for Next.js; Preview URLs, instant rollback; Serverless/Edge Functions; global Edge Network with strong performance
Hobby plan has traffic/request/function quotas; limited large backend capacity; repo size and deploys capped
Lovable
AI-assisted generation of frontend, backend, and database; WYSIWYG editor; one-click deploy with domain binding; free trial for full workflow
Backend tied to services like Supabase; complex projects need engineers; frequent feature changes, small quotas, unclear long-term roadmap

blocks.title: Paid Hosting Platforms Comparison
rows: AWS
Most comprehensive cloud services; S3 + CloudFront/Amplify cover many architectures; highly scalable and secure; pay-as-you-go pricing
Steep learning curve, complex setup; complicated cost structure requiring monitoring; infrastructure maintenance on user
WordPress.com
Mature CMS with plugin ecosystem (from business plan); quick content site launch; free to start with upgrade flexibility
Lower-tier plans block plugins; PHP-based with limited frontend customization; high traffic may be affected by shared resources
Wix
Drag-and-drop editor with rich templates; app store plus SEO/marketing tools; hosting and maintenance included, low admin overhead
Limited code freedom; vendor lock-in, hard to migrate; advanced/e-commerce features costlier
Squarespace
High-quality, consistent templates; strong official feature integration; great mobile experience with solid support
No permanent free plan; less flexible than Wix or self-hosting; smaller plugin ecosystem, limited customization

blocks.content: Demo: Deploying a Small Site to Vercel (Typical Workflow)

items: Prepare a site (with index.html) and push it to a GitHub Repository.
Log in to Vercel (GitHub login supported).
In the Vercel console, select **New Project**.
Authorize and link the GitHub Repository.
Select the project, Vercel auto-detects and configures it.
After deployment, Vercel provides a default domain for public access.

blocks.alt: Demo: auto-deploy a static site from GitHub to Vercel

blocks.content: üìå Any time you push updates to GitHub, Vercel auto-redeploys, keeping the site up to date.

blocks.title: Tip
blocks.content: Both Netlify and Vercel support auto-deployment via GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket. Push code, and the site updates automatically.
